taxonAuthor: R.J Anderson, H. R Simons & J.J. Bolton, 1988

texts.shortText: Forms large, dark greenish-brown crusts covering open rock surfaces (rarely shells) from the low water mark to about 10 m depth. Surface smooth and quite slippery and with a well-defined, fairly regular margin. Lower surface attached by numerous short rhizoids.
1-2 mm thick with colonies typically up to 10 mm across, but sometimes much larger, covering whole boulders.

Global: South African endemic.

Local/Regional: Yzerfontein on west coast to Eastern Cape.

Common encrusting species covering large areas of rock from very low intertidal pools to about 10 m depth. Forms gardens defended and grazed on by the Giant limpet Scutellastra tabularis. This is the only known species in the fairly recently erected family Zeacarpaceae.
Tiny elongate sporangia, each of which produces 16 spores when mature, are borne in groups in the surface of the thallus.
Could be confused with the encrustng red alga Hildenbrandia lecannellieri, which forms similar large dark crusts, but that has a gnarled rough surface and normally occurs higher in the shore.
